content: The "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" includes a temporary deduction for certain mortgage counseling under section 224 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" allows individuals to deduct up to $500 for qualified mortgage counseling provided by an FHA-accredited organization before obtaining a loan on their principal residence. The deduction for mortgage counseling under the "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" is allowed for amounts paid or incurred before December 31, 2012. The deduction is included in computing adjusted gross income and is listed as section 224 in the tax code. The "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" allows a deduction for mortgage counseling until December 31, 2012. Section 224 in the tax code pertains to this deduction. Section 225 addresses upside-down mortgages, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. The tax code allows a deduction of 20% of excess acquisition indebtedness for an individual's principal residence, limited to $5,000 per year. Fraudulently obtained mortgages are not eligible for this deduction. Acquisition indebtedness for a principal residence deduction is not allowed if taxpayer made material misstatements. The deduction is terminated for amounts paid after December 31, 2009. Upside down mortgages are included in the deduction. Section numbers in the tax code are amended accordingly. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. A new section is added to allow a credit for certain home purchases. The amendments apply to taxable years after December 31, 2007. A credit is allowed for individuals purchasing a qualified principal residence, equal to 10% of the purchase price or $7,500 ($9,000 in high-cost areas). The credit is divided equally over two taxable years. The tax credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is limited to purchases made within 12 months after the enactment of the section. The credit amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The tax credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is limited based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, with specific ratios and limitations outlined. The tax credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is limited based on the amount of tax, with specific calculations and one-time only allowance for married individuals. The tax credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is limited to one per individual or spouse, and joint purchases by multiple individuals are also restricted from claiming the credit. The definition of a qualified principal residence is specified in the section. The tax credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is limited to one per individual or spouse, and joint purchases by multiple individuals are also restricted from claiming the credit. The term 'qualified principal residence' refers to a residence purchased to be the purchaser's principal residence, with specific conditions for recapture if the residence is disposed of or not occupied as the principal residence within 24 months. The tax credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is subject to recapture if the taxpayer fails to occupy the residence as their principal residence within 24 months of purchase. Special rules apply for joint purchases, with adjustments for married individuals filing separately and unmarried individuals. The tax credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence can be allocated among unmarried individuals purchasing together, with a maximum credit of $7,000. Rules similar to section 1400C apply for purchase and reporting requirements. For the tax credit on purchasing a qualified principal residence, rules similar to section 1400C apply for reporting requirements. The basis of the residence is reduced by the amount of the credit allowed. Conforming amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code, including inserting sections 23 and 25E, amending sections 25D(c)(2), 26(a)(1), 904(i), 1016(a), and 1400C(d)(2) to include references to section 25E. Section 1400C(d)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include reference to section 25E. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections to insert a new item after section 25D. Section 25E provides a credit for certain home purchases, effective for taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. The amendment is subject to the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001. Additionally, there is a temporary additional standard deduction for real property taxes for nonitemizers. The amendment adds a real property tax deduction for taxable years 2008 and 2009, limited to $500 ($1,000 for joint filers). Eligible State and local real property taxes can be deducted under this provision. The amendment allows for a deduction of eligible state and local real property taxes up to $500 ($1,000 for joint filers) for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. SEC. 6. TEMPORARY EXCLUSION OF UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION FROM GROSS INCOME. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude unemployment compensation from gross income for individuals in 2008 and 2009. Effective for amounts received after December 31, 2007.
